subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running Multiple Fixtures in junit.swingui.TestRunner
msgSnippet: ... What you just snipped out was taken directly from the JUnit Web site. Just to keep things clear, let s put it back in: Tests need to run against the
messageBody:
On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> > > Ah.. but in proper usage TestCase == fixture... so I have no argument
> > > with his use of the word... assuming he's doing it "right" (i.e. his
> > > TestCase is maximally cohesive)
> >
> > Oh. Proper usage. From the Fixture section on JUnit Web site:
> <snip />

What you just snipped out was taken directly from the JUnit Web site.
Just to keep things clear, let's put it back in:

"Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects. This
set of objects is called a test fixture. When you are writing tests you
will often find that you spend more time writing the code to set up the
fixture than you do in actually testing values."

Pay close attention, class. The set of objects is the fixture. The
fixture is what you set up. This is clear and unambiguous English from
the authors of JUnit.

> Let us try this again, with one slight correction.
>
> "Ah.. but in proper usage each fixture is a different TestCase class..."

Now, either

* this "correction" is also from the JUnit site, in which case they have
contradicted themselves, or

* this is simply your interpretation, in which case you should defer to
what the authors of JUnit.

Which is it? Searching on the Web page I gave a URL for, I just don't
find the phrase "in proper usage".

For that matter, if I google I get

Your search - junit "each fixture is a different TestCase class" -
did not match any documents.

Googling on a shorter phrase gives me the same result

Your search - junit "different TestCase class" - did not match any
documents.

It would seem that if this text appears anywhere, Google hasn't noticed
it.

> "test case" (as used in the document Jim quoted) == instance of
> TestCase, usually implemented as a method on a TestCase class
>
> "fixture" == TestCase class
>
> OK?

Not really. A TestCase always contains a fixture. This may or may not
be clearly distinguished by putting it in a setUp() method, but it's the
set of objects that you are running your test against.

If we are going to be truly nitpicking, then recall that an object is an
INSTANCE of a class. A set of objects can never be a class. It is a set
of instances of a set of classes.


My apologies to the wider world for starting this absurd thread; I was
just trying to be helpful to the enquirer.

--
